conclusion: To find the power of the external force doing work on the rotating conductor rod OC in the magnetic field, we need to consider the electromagnetic induction and the resulting current and force interactions.
As the rod OC rotates with angular velocity ω, it sweeps out an area in the magnetic field.

premise: The length of the rod OC is r. The linear velocity v of the end of the rod is v = ωr.
conclusion: The induced EMF (𝓔) in the rod is given by: 𝓔 = B ⋅ l ⋅ v = B ⋅ r ⋅ (ωr) = Bωr²

premise: The induced EMF drives a current I through the resistor R.
conclusion: Using Ohm's Law: I = 𝓔/R = Bωr²/R

premise: The current-carrying rod OC experiences a magnetic force due to the magnetic field B.
conclusion: The force F on the rod is: F = I ⋅ l ⋅ B = I ⋅ r ⋅ B = (Bωr²/R) ⋅ r ⋅ B = B²ωr³/R

premise: The external force must counteract this magnetic force to maintain the uniform rotation of the rod.
conclusion: The power P delivered by the external force is the product of the force and the linear velocity of the point of application (which is the end of the rod): P = F ⋅ v = (B²ωr³/R) ⋅ (ωr) = B²ω²r⁴/R
